The Frattini subgroup of a finite group is .

Let $\Frat G$ denote the Frattini subgroup of a finite group $G$. Let
$S$ be a Sylow subgroup of $\Frat G$. Then by the Frattini argument,
$G=\Frat{G}N_G(S)=\genby{\Frat G\cup N_G(S)}$. But the Frattini subgroup
is finite and formed of non-generators, so it follows that
$G=\genby{N_G(S)}=N_G(S)$. Thus $S$ is normal in $G$, and therefore
normal in $\Frat G$. The result now follows, as .

In fact, the same proof shows that for any group $G$, if $\Frat G$ is
finite then $\Frat G$ is nilpotent.
